content:
Posted: May 12, 2016
												Hyper Light Drifter can be best described as a mixture between The Legend of Zelda and Dark Souls. The game is difficult, but fair and, like Dark Souls, the story is never handed to you and if you want to know whats going on youre going to have to explore a lot. The game also has a total of four dungeons, that can be beaten in any order, well except for the South dungeon. The combat animations are fluid and the mixture of Sword and gun combat is quite satisfying. It is also very dash heavy as it is the only way to avoid enemy attacks. All upgrades can be purchased in any order from the start of the game, but the currency is somewhat scarce and hard to find so pick your upgrades wisely. The games lenghth is around 8 to 10 on your first play through and there are new game plus options for those completionists out there. The only cons I could think of is that there are no words said or spoken by any characters in the game, thus leaving you confused as to what the heck is going on, but if you like that type of story then more power to you. There are also occasional bugs were the a cutscene might trigger too early. The game is also locked at 30 fps so if you cant stand that beware.I would highly recommend this game to all fans of Zelda's combat and Dark Soul's style of story telling, and despite it's minor flaws I believe the art style and combat system are well worth the price of admission.

												Hyper Light Drifter is pretty much what I expected. Top down, 2D Zelda-ish gameplay but with more emphasis on combat. I've been following the development of this game for a year or so now and I'm really happy with the finished product. Gameplay is really solid and the minimalistic nature of the art and storytelling within the game is nice too. I felt that the game was a little bit too short but it was still fun; the trailer made it seem like it was going to be bigger than just four areas/bosses. Replaying the game to find all the secrets and to get all the upgrades is pretty much the only reason I would play it again. It's a really solid game with challenging combat, but the only downside is that it's locked at 30 fps. It didn't bother me too much, but I know people who would not be happy with that. Definitely recommend playing with a controller. All in all, a really fun game for its combat, art, and interesting world building.

												Incredibly well made 2D roleplay exploration based game. Sountrack is absolutely echanting, visuals never get boring to the eye.Certain nitpicks:- Confusing storyline throughout the first hours of playing the game. It does get clearer and clearer while you keep playing, though. - Not so amazing boss fights. The last one is an exception. (that was so ♥♥♥♥in cool)- Clunky movement mechanics. You'll often find yourself accidentally falling out of the world.- A lot of walking. A lot of it. That also includes a lot of backtracking in order to find extra modules/gearbits/or monoliths. Not much of a big deal, but there's people who don't like this sort of thing. - Some secret passageways would be impossible to find out unless you were dashing around every single centimeter in a level. The game often shows you where a secret passageway might be located by placing a symbol on the edge of a plataform, though, so I guess that compensates the nearly imposssible-to-find passageways. Other than that I can safely say I really enjoyed playing this game. Combat mechanics are absolutely fun to mess around with, several ways to defeat enemies (not only with your sword). Difficulty gradually increases when you progress throughout the game, health packs are distributed evenly, enemy spawn system keeps you atentive enough and ready to jump into action through out the entire game, a whole variety of levels to explore, different enemy mechanics, ect...  did I also say its graphics are gorgeous? Oh yeah, definitely. I love me some eye candy every once in a while.Thanks to my bro Choppa for the game, too. You're awesome dude. Had a lot of fun with this game c:.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2016
												This game has mad style. Immediately, you’ll notice the pixel art is top notch. There are gorgeous vistas to stop and take a gander at when you’re not too busy with the fast-paced combat or looking for secrets. You’ll behold a devastated world filled with remnants of the past in 4 different environments located at each of the cardinal directions (NWES). The storytelling mostly comes from interpreting images and your surroundings as the games has no dialogue. Sometimes what’s happening is obvious because a bloody corpse says it blatantly. The game also runs only at 30fps which is puzzling considering how much zipping around you’ll be doing.Look at that view:


Hyper Light Drifter 
A Screenshot of Hyper Light Drifter
By: Jamfrost Jamiro




Now, the game doesn’t explain much and while that gives it an air of mystery with the story, it works against it in other parts. Do not accidentally sabotage your playthrough with poor initial upgrade purchases. Upgrades requires Gearbits and you need to find four pieces of them to make one. Making a bad upgrade purchase can cause large amounts of suffering because the combat/mobility upgrades should take priority over anything else. My recommended upgrade path is the sword projectile reflect and chain dodge first, then the dodge projectile shield. From there you can safely branch out and grab whatever upgrade you want. I foolishly grabbed an ammo upgrade before grabbing the sword projectile reflect ability which gave me some serious problems in the Eastern Zone with the ranged enemies. Don’t do what I did. Also know that you can fast travel at almost any time to an activated waypoint, so don’t be afraid to try out the other paths to find more bits. Combat isn’t about pulling off sweet 100-hit combos and increasing the score multiplier. It’s about timing, mobility, positioning, and skilled execution. You’ll find yourself frequently dodging to and from enemies as you quickly decide to attack or retreat. Dodges don’t have any invincibility frames and enemies have collision so move carefully. Your character will have access to different guns, starting with the pistol. However, the aiming mechanic is extremely clunky. You hold Left Trigger to pull out the gun, aim with the Left Stick, and then fire with the Right Trigger. Your character has to stand still during that whole process which can mean taking hits while trying to shoot. Aiming my shot by facing the enemy before squeezing the Right Trigger worked out much better, especially with the shotgun. For example, you can dodge or run towards an enemy, fire away with RT, then dodge/run away, all without bothering with the terrible aiming mechanic. Hitting with the sword and then firing right after works well too. You’ll need to watch out for enemies or hazards that can knock you down because you’re not safe on the ground. You can be killed while lying down and some bosses will knock the wind out of you.Each zone has a big bad and those bosses are all about learning patterns and using your tools. They’re not easy foes. I’ve died to all the bosses multiple times before emerging victorious. They have a set pattern and a pattern changeup once you remove enough of their health. Usually this means they’ll speed up, add another attack, or possibly summon adds (enemies). I found myself counting their attacks and looking for their tells in order to overcome them. If you pay enough attention, each attempt will bring you closer to victory as you learn their tactics and counter with your own. I really liked the final boss. The fight was a satisfying and challenging experience. I defeated it with a well-executed reflection of 8-10 projectiles at point blank range. That felt way too good. Mmm.Finally, in addition to the upgrade woes I mentioned earlier, there are other areas where this game stumbles. The map isn’t very helpful and doesn’t mark any of the collectables except for modules, things necessary for game progression though you can find bonus ones. Its rooms are displayed as basic shapes with the paths that connect them. Your player icon will not be accurately positioned to your true location. I didn’t use it much except for fast traveling and occasional path checking for making sure I’m heading down the right chain of rooms when underground.The chain/infinite dodge never felt responsive to me and was sometimes hard to control. This issue could be related to the game running at 30fps. I am not sure. The chain dodge is the main method of traveling quickly. It’s also much faster than the normal 3 dodges at a time. The issue comes from the timing which struggles to feel consistent. Also, the more chain dodges you manage, the faster the timing becomes and those windows are very picky. Sometimes you’ll come to a dead stop if your second button press is off. Or you’ll mess up a third or fourth press which makes your character slide for a considerable amount of distance. The slide looks cool until you realize you’re going off a platform. Sometimes you’ll just slam into a wall and bounce when zipping around. I fell off platforms quite often and I had moments where my second button press left me on top of a disappearing platform instead of starting the chain. For the most part, chain dodging is manageable despite the false starts and slides. It’s also fun when you figure out the tempo, but its unreliability becomes a major problem when trying do some of the optional activities.My last criticism is about how some of the secrets are handled in this title. In short, some of them are either tedious, frustrating, or both. One of them involves reaching a chain dodge number of 800 in the dodge shop. That’s 800 dodges in a row which is possible with the upgrade, but maybe should be avoided. I think my top score was around 60 or more. There was also this crystal room with a cosmetic reward at the end. You had to navigate a long and winding hall with 90 degree turns where the floor was mostly covered with crystal hazards by chain dodging. These crystals turn into big dangerous crystals soon after you pass over them that knock you down for 2 damage. My knocked out character would sometimes land on other crystals and succumb to a fatal crystal chain. If you manage to pass all the hazards, you’re then greeted by a room full of mobs and crystal spiders that encase you in a crystal if they touch you. You can take damage and be killed while encased and have to start from the beginning. That place showed me how flawed the chain dodge was. Or maybe that was a bad room. Throughout the game, I just wasn’t too enthusiastic about secrets unless they were hidden Gearbit pieces. Overall, the game provided me with a good experience, a memorable final boss fight, sweet tunes, and a great amount of style. The game could have been better in the areas I’ve mentioned before, especially with that map. The movement and combat could have benefited from having 60fps.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2016
												Hyper Light Drifter is somewhat a mixed bag of the game.On one hand we have absolutely gorgeous graphics and amazing soundtrack, solid combat and awesome boss fights.The game feels like a mix of Souls and Zelda. It's definitely not an easy game, nor does it tells you anything about the world directly (there are literally no words in game beyond menu).Vibrant colors and very interesting world only adds to the great atmosphere this game has.Just exploring for secrets is a joy, in my opinion.Melee combat feels pretty solid, all enemies have their own attack patterns that you have to learn, bosses are amazing to fight against.Storyline is.. hm.. I guess "intriguing" would be the best word here. Since you'll have to figure it out yourself from a set of images. Some people actually called it "lazy" (it might as well be so), but I'd found it to be pretty interesting.On other hand we have a bunch of very annoying things - 30fps lock, very poorly thought through aiming system, poor keyboard and mouse support, lackluster progression system.I mean, you can still play with all of those, they are definitely not game breaking.But missing a crucial shot or dashing off the cliff is not that unusual for this game. And considering how hard can some of the battles be - this might be mildly infuriating.Progression system is probably my biggest gripe here - it could've been so much more, yet it's just a bunch of unlock that you cannot get unless you explore for secrets to find currency for them. And some of those are really well hidden and can take a while to find. Not everyone will like that.So, if you can ignore those issues and just play the game for the world, exploration and boss fights - you'll find to enjoy it quite a bit.Watch my video for more in-depth look here:

content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
 (I’m new at “officially” reviewing things, so bear with me please.) First off, I  absolutely   recommend this game to anyone who’s considering buying it; however, I will warn that for some people it might be a tougher game than you'd think. That being said, the controls are rather intuitive (I played with a controller, so I can’t really speak for the keyboard and mouse experience), and I would advise that you don’t be afraid to experiment a bit in how you do things in order to find the best method for you. Second, advice if you do play the game: dodge, and dodge often, at least until  you get the ability to reflect bullets with your sword and/or dodge through bullet attacks without taking damage, and then it becomes dodge and reflect often .****************************************************************** Hyper Light Drifter is a game that’s far from easy, but not impossible either. The gameplay is very smooth and the controls are relatively easy to learn — but that doesn’t mean you’ll be  good  at everything right away. You’re thrown into a world that gives you very little and allows you to figure things out for yourself; in a sense, what you put into it is what you get out of it (particularly in terms of the story, but I’ll get to that in a bit). It’s a game that rewards you for secret-hunting, so be on the lookout for everything from secret passages to areas that you can dash to. You will die, and you’ll probably die often. And it will be frustrating at times (at least it was for me). But you’ll find yourself getting back up to try again and again until you get it, and that sense of accomplishment is oh-so-sweet once you make it. The art in this game is absolutely gorgeous — the lighting is extremely well done, the colors are lovely, and I was surprised when I realized the reason everything looks so  smooth  is that the typical outline you see in pixel art is not there. The animations are extremely smooth, and even the death and resurrection animations are good (I will say I’m extremely glad they patched in the ability to speed up the resurrection animation, especially when you’re dying multiple times trying to defeat a boss). The music and sound design in general is absolutely beautiful as well, to the point where I’m still not tired of hearing it even after having a track loop for 30+ minutes straight as I try to defeat a boss. The details in this game are extremely impressive, from the way your blood drops dissolve off the ground to the little victory sword thing your Drifter does when finishing a harder fight. The entire game progresses without a single word, everything being explained through pictures (or in the case of upgrades, little animations) and cutscenes; and yet, I feel like understood the story as well as I personally could have. The “important” characters (those that do more than make a little noise at you when you "ping" them) have their backstories told through pictures as well, and I felt oddly connected to them despite not having what would normally be considered "in-depth" information about them. Especially true for me in the case of  the other Drifter (possibly?), who’s in the same situation as you, or at least it seems that way . And I won’t lie — the ending gave me a few emotions, at least the way that I interpreted it. All in all, this game is fantastic and I will definitely be playing quite a bit more of it to see what I can find and/or do. This is absolutely a game I recommend.

Posted: March 31, 2016
												Hyper Light Drifter is an adventure game with fantastic atmosphere. The combat, while so far a bit basic, is well made and you are required to watch the attack patterns of your enemies to find opening. Similar to the Dark Souls games you can heal mid fight, but you are completely vulnerable for a second while you heal. I only fought one boss so far, but the difficulty level seemed perfect. The difficulty outside of boss fights is more on the easy side, since the game hides health packs at every second corner.The world has a beautiful design, that took some heavy inspiration from Neon Genesis Evangelion, and offers quite a bit of freedom for exploration. You are not forced into a linear path, but rather given the choice to explore whichever part of the world you want to start with. The soundtrack has the typical Disasterpeace feel that is reminiscent of FEZ and fits the game quite nicely.So far I haven't run into any major bugs, only some animals that were stuck running into a wall and one or two walls that you could walk through that didn't seem intentional. However one major issues with the game is the lock to 30 fps. While it is perfectly playable at that framerate it would look a lot smoother in 60 fps.

												I just finished the game a few minutes ago before writing this and I must say I have mixed feelings. The Good: Amazing sound and visual design,  solid dash mechanics. the well designed bossfights.The Bad: Swordplay feels stilted, the story is handled poorly( I don't even think there was one), the map more often then not does not help, enemy placement half the time felt  ill-thought-out, it is not fun to rub your face against walls for hours.On the Kickstarter page they promised a much lager game with an actual story, but when I play Drifter I feel as if there is no purpose as to why I am trying to collect shards. I feel they were going for an old school zelda 1 feel but it falls flat story wise, even for a game that is solely about adventuring.  In zelda 1 the game clues you in to why you have to collect the tri-force pieces. you collect them to save Zelda and to have a chance to stop Gannon. In drifter though you collect shards for access to boss rooms? (i'll edit this part when I go back in if i'm just being an idiot). If you collect 4 you are privy to a meaningless cutscene that basicly shows you the opening again. What i'm getting at is the story feels so pretentious  that the team forgot to write a story with purpose. I'm all for no word storytelling, but they dropped the ball on this one.TL;DR The game sufferd from the Peter Molyneux Effect and it was so close to acheivng what I belive the team set out to make, but they just wern't there.Would I recomend the game? 												I would very much love to recommend this game. But sadly I can't. And here's why.The combat is very fast and relies on you dodging enemy attacks and then punishing them in their vunerable state. It reminds me of Souls games and Bloodborne. However where those games boast fantastic responsiveness and robust controls this game falls flat on it's face and completely ruins the whole experience,Controls are very unreliable. Sometimes you dodge, sometimes you don't because even if you press the button in time your character will not respond to your input. The easiest way to check this issue is try dodging several times in a row when not in combat. You'll quickly see what I mean.Framerate drops are constant on the upper-middle class rig that runs DSIII on 60fps no problem,Perhaps the Game Maker Studio used to make HLD is to blame but regarless it is a frustrating experience.Game's art direction is worthy of mentioning because this is a gem to look at. Locations are pretty and there are some nods to classic games with way better controls.No matter how apealing this game looks on the surface stay away.To further prove my point here's a review by Super Bunnyhop:

Posted: April 9, 2016
												To begin, the art and ambient soundtrack is astounding. It really immerses you into the game and sets the tone for the plot. Second, the combat is simple to learn, yet hard to master. You can swing your sword, and shoot a gun. Eventually, you can pick up upgrades that may require you to dash and swing your sword in quick succession, but that is really all there is to it. The enemies are made to be very challenging, so you will need to play smart and never take uneccessary damage in order to preserve as much life as possible. Finally, there are many secrets in this game, and even times when you need to look for something vital to completing the game, it could be hidden. I don't want to spoil anything, but always pay attention to your surroundings and look around very thoroughly in order to get the best experience you can for this game. Nothing in this game bothered me enough to mention, but everyone is different. A thing to mention is the story is very interesting yet hard to comprehend. You pretty much have to imagine a lot of the sotry for yourself, but there are times when you can piece bits of the intended story together based on environment, bosses, and interacting with NPCs (That do not talk in any other way besides showing you pictures) Essentially, if you are not into the types of games that do not hold your hand and tell you where to go, you will dislike this game. Come into this 7-9 hour game expecting a challenge, because that is what you are going to get. I hope many people come to purchase this game and support the developers that worked very hard on creating a game that is memorable in every aspect. I absolutely recommend this game to anyone who likes action - RPGs and enjoy dying a lot :DFINAL VERDICT: Art - 10Soundtrack - 9Combat - 9Story - 9

Posted: April 7, 2016
												Instead of a review, how about obtuse comparisons for every gamer?For fans of indie games: imagine Transistor.  Take away the ability to pause combat, and imagine a much more visceral and immediate gaming experience.  You have to plan your approach to combat in this game, but you don't have the luxury of the pause, zoom out, carefully place precise movements phase of combat: everything happens quite quickly.  The game is just as beautiful, but in a more ambient (sountrack) and expansive (world) way.For fans of Japanese action rpgs: imagine a later Ys game.  Now give yourself a gun.  Cover with a layer of lovely pixelated aesthetic flair.And now a comparison that should work for any gamer: Hyper Light Drifter is a Zelda game that really makes you work for it.One last thing: don't imagine Dark Souls.  Yes, the game is difficult.  Yes, the story is told in an organic, non-scripted way.  But the above comparisons give you a better idea of how the game plays.EDIT: Just updating to say the developers have continued to add great content: still a great game I'd wholeheartedly recommend.

												Hyper Light Drifter is a game that I have been looking forward to playing for quite some time. I feared a little that my excitement for the game may cause disappointment when things didn't meet expectations, but I was pleasantly suprised by just how well executed everything turned out to be.The artstyle is simply gorgeous, done in an 8-bit style to extremely great effect; and combined with the well polished soundtrack, Hyper Light Drifter succeeds in reaching a very high overall quality. The gampeplay itself is quite engaging, with a large emphasis on evasion and hit-and-run tactics, which combined with the unforgiving health system, makes for plenty of very intense engagements. In addition, I beat every boss in the game (optional and mandatory), and every single one was very unique to fight.My only two complaints are quite minor. The first was that in doing a lot of exploring, I spent a lot of time listening to the one track associated with the area I was in. This was eased somewhat in the high overall quality of the soundtrack, but after some time looking around, listening to one theme the entire time did begin to grow a little stale.My second complaint was that I experienced a bug around bosses, where after reloading to try again, the game would autosave after I would use a medkit to bring my character to full health. This meant that each time I retried, I lost a medkit until I eventually had none left.Other than that though, this game was a pleasure to play through, and my seven hours to complete the game were very well spent.★★★☆☆

												Hyper Light Drifter is a 2D action game in the style of early Legend of Zelda games, specifically A Link to the Past for the SNES, as the game features a top down camera and involves exploring an overworld with several small dungeons tucked away. Furthermore, the launch was crippled by FPS drops, but it has since been patched out and the game ran without any issues for the duration of my first playthrough.The Good:+Excellent combat that relies on timing and mastery of the players abilities.+Fluid pixel art that is easy on the eyes.+Fantastic music by Disasterpiece, the same artist that produced the music for Fez and Shoot Many Robots.+Lots of secrets, hidden paths and upgrades hidden around every corner of the map and dungeons.+The story and narrative is told without dialogue, much like Journey was, which makes for a different experience.+Enviromental puzzles and challenges break up the hack and slash action.The Bad:-The game has superb boss fights, but could've used more, especially since the last zone featured more than one.-Some enemies will knock your character over and hit you again, before you can dodge away, leading to cheap deaths.-Due to opting out of dialogue the story does seem somewhat shallow.-Secrets fall between just being in a corner or having incredibly obtuse sollutions that aren't always explained.Bottom Line: Hyper Light Drifter is a love letter to old retro games and flaunts great gameplay, tells a simplistic story and at times, delivers crushing difficulty. For those looking for a retro challenge this is it, however those looking for less action and more pure exploration should look elsewhere.

												This game is the first and only one for which I have ever felt the need to write a review for. Honestly I wasn't expecting too much out of this when I first purchased it. I watched the trailers beforehand and figured it would be a pretty average/so-so game that I would work on every so often out of boredom. Boy was I WRONG. I found myself immediately intrigued when the opening cut scene started to play on the screen after creating my character save. It made me curious as to what was going on and what exactly this story would be about. Even after completing the game (after about 8 hours) I was still left wondering what exactly was the cause/source of the dilemma which your character faces. I suppose that is to be somewhat expected from a game with absolutely no dialogue whatsoever.The occasional picture based “dialogues” that you would encounter with a few characters throughout the game would give you a general idea of what to watch out for and where to go, but beyond that the grand plot of the story was left somewhat to speculation. However, I would not count this as a con at all. Quite the contrary, actually; it left it to the imagination as to how this world you play in came to be.With that being said, this game is perhaps one of the best I have ever played. It’s simple style, yet complex and diverse atmosphere was breathtaking in its own special way, and the adventure/puzzle/mystery style of it all really made it something that I could not put down. I played it at every chance I could get until I was finished.However, as fun as this game is, it is equally challenging and at times VERY frustrating. It isn’t too hard to figure out the puzzles and places that you need to go in order to acquire the necessary items to progress, but some of the fighting areas (and ESPECIALLY the boss fights) are rather grueling. This is no pushover game when it comes to combat. Some of the mob fights took several tries, and the boss battles took many, many more. What’s more is that it is rather difficult to find health, as it exists in scarcity across the games landscape and dungeons. May Heaven, Hell, and all the hosts that lie within them help you if you happen to enter a big fight without enough health and reserve health. Don’t expect to come out victorious by just “winging it.” It’s difficulty and required persistence WILL make you want to rage quit several times. Period. But not in a bad way… if that makes sense.Overall, for the price that I paid and the experience that I got out of it, I would definitely recommend this game to anyone who is looking for a fun and enjoyable (and, again, challenging) way to kill time. Just be prepared to devote some time and patience when going into it. 10/10 would pay and play again.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
												Hyper Light Drifter's (HLD) flashy fast style and sharp art direction will draw you into its world and its steeply difficult to master mechanics will keep you engaged (if that's your thing). Reward stems solely from learning the intricacies of combat. With a few unlockable abilities you are highly mobile, easily able to evade or deflect any incoming attack. But, executing these moves with confidence takes practice and HLD doesn't shy away from punishing you for your errors.Like the most successful action games, HLD is undeniably cool and stimulating when you fall into its flow. But, this rhythm-harmony is hard to achieve, demanding practice and your undivided attention. Lose it and you'll find yourself completely open to attack or looking at the black death screen -- your colorful sprite lying in a pool of his own blood. Combat is HLD's most interesting element. You are equipped with a sword that has a single attack combo and a pistol that recharges whenever you attack with the sword. The pistol is just as useful as the sword--even in boss fights--which is an unexpected triumph. Enemies with 2 or 3 hit points can be disposed of with one sword combo, a few pistol shots, or a couple reflected projectiles. Those with more health need a few sword combos and a few shots to take down. But, after completing a single 3-swing combo, your sprite is locked in a sort-of rest animation that leaves you open to attack. Each sword strike has to be timed and enemies never get stunned. Mess up the dash's galloping rhythm and your sprite will slide across the ground for a couple seconds as you helplessly try to regain control. Some guns(yes, there is more than one) have a short cooldown in between shots that can really throw you off if you're not careful. But these moments where, suddenly, combat grinds to halt for a brief couple of seconds really separates it from a generic hack 'n slash requiring little-to-no deliberation. With life-threatening challenges around every corner, satisfaction arises from skill-based consistency in battle. This may be a point of issue for some. The nonlinear structure of the game means every area has a similar level of difficulty (excluding the Southern area which isn't immediately accessible). The hardest area will most likely be your first. Although, if you care enough to explore the late game content, there are rooms that will definitely test your skills. But, these rooms always feel extra and are never necessary for progressing through the main game.HLD presents itself as a very mysterious game and its ambiguity harms more than it helps. NPCs speak in hieroglyphics that resemble symbols you've seen elsewhere. A monitor in your bedroom displays a cryptic diagram. Nothing is explained, save for a few basic controls. After a few hours you will know everything the game has to offer and be left with the matter of finding them. The problem is that you'll think the game has more to offer than it actually does. Much like the NPCs that tell stories in slide-show form, these mysteries are to be seen, not to engage with. They are surface level, solely there to build the world, not to solve. On the whole, the ambiguity of its story, characters, and goal prevents HLD from building tension around any particular confrontation or moment. HLD tries to with it short opening cinematic, NPC stories, and one reoccurring nightmare sequence but it's all too little and all too vague. This, coupled with the game's open structure, results in an experience that never escalates to a satisfying conclusion. However, the game has a consistent, dark tone and an atmosphere that is filled with dread. Visually, the game can be dark and frightening as you journey far below the surface. It can be bright and beautiful as you wander through a crystal forest and even epic, with once mobile giants, now forever petrified in stoic backgrounds. HLD combines sci-fi and fantasy in a unique way and it is difficult to not be drawn into its world.Individual areas are visually and structurally different, distinctly separate from one another.Unlike the game as a whole, each area escalates in the form of sequentially more difficult arena-style battles, climaxing with a boss encounter. Areas will have their own enemy types and combinations, often mixed together in a way that will keep you constantly juggling strategies. Boss fights present proper challenges, spurring the ferocity of combat to new heights in two-phase, lengthy confrontations. Enemy and boss design are both well-done and serve as one of HLD's strongest features.HLD's biggest problem is its exploration. The map is not really all that helpful. There are three things you're looking for in the game: purple triangles, stone tablets, and keys. Purple triangles are the only items that are mandatory for completion and you only need to find half of them. They are displayed on the map, but are still difficult to find. If you don't want to spend countless hours prowling the world for an item, you won't have to. Finding what is necessary for completion is a fun task that gives you proper time to master the deep combat mechanics. But, if you were looking forward to losing yourself in Hyper Light Drifter intriguing world, trying to piece together an various elusive secrets, I suggest you tailor your expectations.After you have found all the purple triangles, the map is useless. The game doesn't aid in your search for the stone tablets and offers no help finding any of the 16 hidden keys. The environments are riddled with hidden passages, offscreen switches, and invisible platforms. If you are trying to collect everything prepare to run along every wall, every side of every platform, and to dash occasionally off a platform just...because...maybe...It starts to feel tedious. Burn every bush with a red candle.The exploration doesn't require any clever use of logic. There are no clues, no puzzles, and really no meaningful reward for end-game exploration. The items you get for finding these secrets are almost always cosmetic. They may boost, for example, the recharge time of your grenades, but nothing you find will alter the way you play the game or the way the game feels. It is a shame that a game with great mechanics fails to offer diversity within them. Only two upgrades, which I acquired quite early in the game, really gave me something new to experiment with, to practice. There is a NG+, where you have 2 hit points and a new outfit. If you are trying to find everything, NG+ is the same exploration with a handicap, but if you are looking for one final test of your combat skills, NG+ will definitely provide it.If you are looking for an indie action game to enjoy casually, a game that eases you into concepts and methods and presents an escalating series of challenges up until the end, this might not be the game for you. HLD is almost always a challenge. Even the earliest enemies have the potential to destroy an experienced player. Still, Hyper Light Drifter's atmosphere, world, and combat are all engaging enough to warrant a purchase and worth a good deal of hours spent exploring.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2016
												If there was ever a game that needed to be recognized for it's genuine labor of love, it should by Hyper Light Drifter, a gorgeous RPG Roguelike that caught my eye many months ago.  I've waited for this baby to show up in the Steam Store, brutal and beautiful, and I was not disappointed by what I saw. In fact, I was quite the opposite - I was most certainly impressed.Read ahead and you too will have no choice but to purchase this DOUBLE fine game:WHAT'S GOOD ABOUT THIS GAME? GRAPHICS - Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ do you see these screenshots? They may be pixel art, but look at the meticulous attention to detail in the enviornment! I'm a sucker for good pixel art, and this game is pretty much the epitome of just that. It's like the developer was playing Dungeon of the Endless in his spare time and wanted to make an ode to Amplitude Studios or something. GAMEPLAY - Hard, but not unfair. The game plays as a explorative rogue-like with an RPG twist, and before I start rambling about how HUGE it is, let's point out exclusively that this game is HARD. You will die constantly if you have never practiced dodging everything on the screen with only a couple of health points to spare. But, it treats like the older brother you love - sternly, but lovingly. STORY - There are no words in this game. Imagine how hard it is to tell a good story with words. Now imagine doing the same thing, without words. Like Redford's movie All is Lost, this game is a marvel to look at through the art and interactions of various mute NPCs.WHAT'S MEDIOCRE ABOUT THIS GAME? STORY - Now, although the story is good to explore without words, the game is incredibly vague. You have an idea of what is going on with the corruption (if that's what it is?), but without any solid context, you are writing your own story as you good. I don't believe that was what the developer was going for, so he cut a little short here. Still, not too bad - you can still grasp the general idea of your blue hero. TUTORIAL - While I do not particularly enjoy the idea of giving mandatory tutorials, an optional one would've absolutely lovely. Or even a training course incorporated into your city hub. Because the monsters outside of said hub are unrelentless, I would've liked it if I, the noobie, could've practiced dodging shots and dashing side to side. Alas, I had to learn the hard way.WHAT'S BAD ABOUT THIS GAME? ART - Not the art design, execution, etc. but the fact that I don't know whether the thing I'm jump on is actually a ledge or just a decoration. I can jump on floating islands and boats, but is that lily pad a way to a secret? Nope, there goes a health point. Perhaps if the pointer changed colors or something to indicate that you can actually land on that texture, it would've been MASSIVELY helpful. For a game that's based on exploration, I find it unacceptable to have my hero drown himself over and over again because lilies are not made for standing.This is one of those few games that I did not have to wait for a sale to buy, and I recommend that you don't wait either. This is game is a blast, and it's always very rewarding to know that you have the mechanical skills (or will achieve them) to outfight, outdodge, and outwit your enemy. Plus, look at those BEAUTIFUL, EXPANSIVE pixel graphics. My eyes sparkle every time.9.5/10

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												Hyper Light Drifter is a game about a world; sure, there’s a lot of fighting and weapons and upgrades (and even a bit of football), but ultimately everything is about the world Heart Machine set out to create. And what a world it winds up being.You start off alone, in the mountains, and sick. Hyper Light Drifter is careful to make your sickness apparent, but never let it weigh you down. Immediately, your presence and purpose is set up – an indeterminate time ago, a catastrophe happened, and you’re at ground zero hoping to find a cure. It’s unclear exactly how you’ll find the cure, but the only hope is the technology of a civilization that destroyed itself.After briefly succumbing to illness, the Drifter wakes up in town, and takes their first steps into the unknown. You get scraps of information from the townspeople: someone of the Drifter’s race was mugged on their travels, the mysterious drifter who saved you has a penchant for defending the weak, and the key to finding the cure is in the center of town.And none of these stories are delivered via words – they are presented through carefully, lovingly drawn images of the events. All of the stories you’ll hear are like this: when you enter a new area, you’ll find out about the area boss’ history through visual recollections of their deeds; when you find a secluded survivor, their tragedy is rendered in detail more explicit than text can easily provide; when you run across the other drifter, he simply sketches on your map.But these encounters are rare. The world of Hyper Light Drifter is a hostile and uncompromising one, which leaves you without friends or sources of information for most of your journey. To compensate, the world around you is the story. You’ll run across houses and people consumed by crystal, and you’ll see the corpses of giants in the distance that you eventually see up close later. As you go, you start to piece together a rough history of the world just by existing in it. Later, when you find that survivor, it provides just enough clarity to establish a foundation of lore, but doesn’t overwhelm what your imagination can come up with. In the end, how you experience Hyper Light Drifter – and, more importantly, how you perceive Hyper Light Drifter – becomes the narrative.It’s also possible to overlook survivors (though they don’t go anywhere, and can be discovered later), which can drastically affect your understanding of the world. The experience of having your own canon superseded by a game is not a common occurrence, but it’s a thrilling experience when pulled off properly. When my Drifter first set out, they were in a hurry to explore: as a player, I wanted to play; as a Drifter, I wanted a cure. As such, I paid little attention to the details around me, and carried out my task and left. When I came back after two more area bosses were defeated, I found the survivor I never spoke to, and all of the details I had overlooked previously were suddenly relevant and ominous.This only accounts for the surface, though. One elevator ride down, and you start finding entirely new fragments of lore that help you piece together what happened in this world. You see drifters that were killed – or possibly killed each other – in their quest to retrieve modules; you never learn the cause of their demise. Beyond a new source of narrative nuance, the buried laboratories help teach you one constant truth in Hyper Light Drifter: everything has a secret.The Drifter is more than proficient at fighting (though how proficient you, as a player are, is another story), so combat is a way to keep the stakes high while you fulfill your true purpose: exploring. You’ll find fake walls, invisible platforms, and cleverly hidden switches, all which take you to new resources, new story, new items, and new clues.And the best part? You won’t know any of this from the get-go. Even as a player who knew there would be secrets to look for, I overlooked several in the first area I went to. But the second area taught me a bit more about how the world of Hyper Light Drifter works, and by the end of the third, I knew a lot. On return, I found secrets I had easily overlooked – ones that didn’t even take upgraded abilities to reach.Which puts Hyper Light Drifter in a really interesting position: it’s Metroidvanian, in a sense, but it rarely gates off areas based on what abilities you have. Rather, Hyper Light Drifter gates off areas based on what you’ve learned about how the world is constructed. There are also gates that require specific areas to be cleared, but you would almost need precognition to find everything in an area your first time through, and that’s what makes exploring so enjoyable.This focus on exploration plays brilliantly with how the game presents its narrative, as you are required to explore to the best of your abilities, and encouraged to discover new ways to explore beyond what you’re used to. As such, you naturally run across tons of ponderous scenes, and uncovering well hidden ones feels extra special.Hyper Light Drifter, to me, is a lot of things: it’s Nausica of the Valley of the Wind, but as a game; it seems like a spiritual successor to Bokura no Taiyō; it’s beautiful sprite graphics in an age where sprite graphics are fading away; it’s ambiguous in its narrative in the best possible ways.Hyper Light Drifter is a game I’ve known I wanted since 2013 – but it’s also a game I’ve longed to see happen for longer than that.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2016
												A really fun game to be had here. Built around exploration and combat, with the most detailed bit of the story appearing in the store description. Anything that can be said in the game is shown with scenery, or described in colourful detail by the few NPCs you encounter. About the only time any English is used is in the menus and the tutorial, making it a lot more accessible to people who aren't as confident with their English language skills.There's a load of secrets to be found dotted around the world, hidden in such a way that you'll miss them the first or second time, then curse yourself out when you find out how to discover everything. The map's expansive to the point where you can easily forget where that one door you can finally unlock was situated, and trying to find a single item can be maddening if you opt to avoid guides.The combat is oodles of fun, being easy to learn and fun to master. Getting a feel for how much damage you can deal before you need to dodge away from enemy attacks makes fighting beasties enjoyable, even against hordes where timing can be difficult to gauge. And if sword-fighting is a questionable prospect, you can take pot-shots at enemies with any of a half-dozen guns you'll find throughout the world. Good luck aiming with a controller, mind - "pot-shot" is about the most accurate you can ask for when seconds spent aiming can allow enemies to take shots back at you, losing you some precious hit-points. Fighting bosses is a barrel of joy with the slash-slash-dodge-dodge gameplay; admittedly, their patterns can be easily sussed out, but their attacks are punishing enough that if you don't learn, you're going to get paddled.Whilst I've certainly gushed about the game, I'm sure you can infer from the previous paragraphs some of the problems I've had with the game. As well as the other problems, a couple of the minigames found in town demand some pretty ridiculous things out of the player, with one of them giving me flashbacks to Spyro 2 regarding its content and difficulty. There have also been times where I've managed to dash myself into locations I shouldn't be, but considering the teleport system, I'm willing to waive 'em.This last point is a minor one, though I have seen a LOT of negativity regarding it in certain locations - the game is programmed to run at 30FPS. I don't know why, and honestly, I don't care, since the game as a whole is rock-solid and easily worth the fifteen quid I put down for it.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												We all knew this was going to be a gorgeous and stunningly detailed pixel tour de force on the graphical front, but how does it play?  Like it was crafted by angels.The exploration is breath takingThe combat is fluid, responsive, challenging, and wholly addictive, almost like how I imagine a top down Dark Souls/Zelda love child would be.The music and is mysterious and sublime, perfectly crafting an atmosphere of wonder, anticipation and ominousness.  The non-verbal and obscure storytelling (which I won’t spoil) is pretty unique for this day and age, and I have been very impressed by the delivery of what little I have seen.It took me 11 hours to finish, and even then I didn't find all the secrets this game has.  I'll need to delve more through the mysterious world of HLD to find them all.I know some people have been moaning about the difficulty, esp the bosses, but i found it just right.  It is challenging and difficult, but never unfair; skill and precision are what you need to get through.  I'm not exactly a hardcore super gamer hero (i struggle through Dark souls and such)  but i found most bosses could fall between 5-10 tries.  You just have to be patiant, concentrate, and learn how to exploit them.  Also, the game is never punishing; after death, you start in the room just before you died with ALL the medikits you have ebfore you entered the room.  that's generousI've also heard a lot of whimpering about this being 30fps.  Cry me a river sweetheart.  It doesn't effect the gameplay, and if little princesses can't cope with 30fps, they shouldn't buy game.  There's been SO much footage of this game on the internet for years, so there's no excuse. I must admit, i would have loved 60fps on this, but lets not go overboard here.Its not a perfect game through.  its not alays clear what it in the foreground, and often i found mself falling of ledges that where blocked by scenery.  also, there's some hit-detection bugs, as i've been shot  through walls a few times, are sometimes a wall has blocked my melee attack but not an enemies.Overall, this is my second fav game of 2016 so far (Dark Souls 3 is currently king) and the best indie game imho since Bastion and Hotline Miami.  I really hope there will be a sequal or spiritual successor in the near future.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2016
												Hyper Light Drifter is a game that I have been looking forward to playing for quite some time. I feared a little that my excitement for the game may cause disappointment when things didn't meet expectations, but I was pleasantly suprised by just how well executed everything turned out to be.The artstyle is simply gorgeous, done in an 8-bit style to extremely great effect; and combined with the well polished soundtrack, Hyper Light Drifter succeeds in reaching a very high overall quality. The gampeplay itself is quite engaging, with a large emphasis on evasion and hit-and-run tactics, which combined with the unforgiving health system, makes for plenty of very intense engagements. In addition, I beat every boss in the game (optional and mandatory), and every single one was very unique to fight.My only two complaints are quite minor. The first was that in doing a lot of exploring, I spent a lot of time listening to the one track associated with the area I was in. This was eased somewhat in the high overall quality of the soundtrack, but after some time looking around, listening to one theme the entire time did begin to grow a little stale.My second complaint was that I experienced a bug around bosses, where after reloading to try again, the game would autosave after I would use a medkit to bring my character to full health. This meant that each time I retried, I lost a medkit until I eventually had none left.Other than that though, this game was a pleasure to play through, and my seven hours to complete the game were very well spent.★★★☆☆

												TL;DR Great game, great graphics.Bosses are very hard but I think the game doesn't want you to engage them early.Really enjoying my time with this game. I expected it to be a 4-6 hours "linear" story but it actually has a somewhat open world and 0 hand holding. First issue I had is that the game doesn't explain anything to you, nothing is in english and nobody speaks english in the game. Until I started playing it was quite hard to understand what all of the things you see mean. For example, the main objective of the game is explained by a hologram where you have 3 images and you don't even know what those 3 images even are until you start actually playing the game.The game has 0 hand holding, meaning you are put into this world, you get somewhat of an explaination about what you have to do and you can go anywhere you want. There are 4 "areas" in which you have to gather some kind of shards that will later I guess activate this thing that is in center of your "hub" area. What I like is that the game doesn't tell you "go here first" but rather "pick any of these paths".One thing that is really bothering me is the aiming with the weapons. I personally don't use controllers that often and this game is certainly designed to be played with one because I encountered some weird stuff going on with keyboard an mouse.I would like if there was some kind of aim assist or actually lock on mode. The game lets you shoot your weapons without aiming as long as you are pointing the desired direction but in middle of the battle you definitely have no time to aim and let alone orient yourself towards enemies. Another thing worth pointing out is the fact that bosses are insanely hard, but I think the game doesn't want you to engage them early on. Because the game lets you explore the whole map I think it wants you to gather upgrade points and get some skills and then go and engage the bosses because going in without a single skill is pretty much suicide. Bosses have insane amount of health while you have only 5 hp and there are hits that do like 3 points of damage, knocks you down and by the time you get up you are dead. I am going to see if the boss battles get any easier later down the road when you get some skills and upgrades but other than that and the aiming I am really enjoying the game.UPDATE:Finally managed to beat 1 boss. Took me like 1 hour... It honestly isn't as hard as it is more developing a tactic and timing your hits/dashes.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												Imagine a Zelda game set in the future. Then pump that up to ELEVEN.In Hyper Light Drifter you play a nameless wandering soldier with a sword on a quest of unknown purpose, plagued by an unknown illness and haunted by nightmares of death and destruction. You aren't given a clear picture of the goal, or even what you should do NEXT most of the time, but that's okay. Much like a classic Zelda game, you have freedom to explore and do as you please, and discover new secrets for yourself, and there are a TON.The game is also much more action-packed. From the start you are equipped with a "dash" function which can be spammed as often as desired (although there is a slight pause after using it 3 times in a row). The primary function of this dash is to let your character leap over short gaps between platforms, but it's also quite useful for dodging and weaving through the battlefield, approaching enemies for the kill and making a quick escape from a big attack. Players will be encouraged to use the dash as much as desired, and mastery will result in some of the flashiest, high-speed ninja fights ever seen in a Zelda-style game!There are shops in town that sell you incredible but not-altogether-necessary upgrades, such as new moves you can do with your sword, more ammo for your guns (THERE ARE GUNS BY THE WAY), and a grenade to add to your movekit.Heavy on story and gameplay with absolutely no dialogue (the game foregoes dialogue in favor of imagery), freedom of exploration reminiscent of oldschool Zelda games and some high-intensity action-packed combat for you hack-and-slash nuts, although calling it that is a dis-service as lack of care or thought given to when and how you move and strike will leave you dead. But, anyway, the game is amazing, okay?Did I mention it's difficult? Punishingly so, at times, but in a good way that makes you feel like you're learning how to do something each time you 'die'.If I have one piece of advice for you, it's start in the east. When you beat it, you get a shotgun!!!

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												This game is the pure definition of "struggle", in both tricky scenarios that the game puts you through, as well as the dialouge-free story that it conveys to the player. Dying goes from a set back to an oppurtunity to try again, and again, and again, until you finally advance after hours of pattern memorization and just plain luck. The vibrant colors mask the bleak atmosphere and surreal visuals the game provides, making it just as terrifying as it is mysterious when you come across more and more of the world. Laslty, the ending perfectly ties the pieces to it all, though it takes some deeper reading and exploration to really understand (this game has a lot of plot related secrets), and serves as an emotional payoff to all the hardwork you did. My only gripe is that the new game plus adds a sort of faux-difficulty by simply lowering your health, though it is only a bonus for most diehard completionists. All in all, Hyper Light Drifter is an solid game that deserves a spot as a Game of the Year, at least for me.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												Hyper Light Drifter is the first game I backed on Kickstarter that's been released and I didn't regret backing. My only real complaint is that I feel it's too short – but I suppose that's better than being too long.The combat is great. After playing the Kickstarter demo late last year, I was unsure of if it was going to be too much of a challenge for me, but I had since acquired a controller and it made a huge difference. The combat is punishingly hard, but not unfairly so – every time I died in this game I knew I had screwed up, that I zigged when I should have zagged. I've read a lot of comparisons to Dark Souls and haven't played those games, but I imagine this is what people mean. In a few cases I wish some of the bosses were a bit harder.As far as the exploration aspects go, the game holds your hand just enough to propel you to the ending. If you want more, to see what's behing those mysterious doors you can't open, to get to those areas just off the edge of your screen, you're going to have to work at it. I've seen some comparisons to Zelda here, but if anything I wish Zelda games were a bit more like HLD.I loved the vibe of this game. Everything from the color scheme and depicition of a world of ancient ruins whose origins we'll never know, the lack of any words or dialog to explain what's going on, and Disasterpeace's amazing soundtrack all fit together to make a world I didn't want to leave.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												GREAT SHOWGOOD SHOW <BAD SHOWAWFUL SHOWA hack and slash game, with a top down-ish perspective. It is mostly inspired by The Legend of Zelda: A Link To the Past, from my personal experience.The game has a beautiful pixel art style, especially the background. And it is well-animated, resulting in tight-but-fluid controls.The gameplay is fast paced but also requires the player to time their attacks and dodges carefully.The enemy designs are simple mostly, but the game always pit you in a room filled with them.This makes the game quite high in difficulty.Another thing that adds to the difficulty is the level design. It's not BAD, but most of the problems I faced is that I often get lost, and the map is not in any way helpful. And looking for secrets in previous stages are a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥♥ This game lacks text, or in-game hints and guides. There are some, but then they give you too much freedom from the beginning of the game.This game, in my opinion, is linear. The "freedom" they gave you only delays your progress. It's good that they give you the freedom to explore, but it doesn't work if there is only one new place you can go at a time. Freedom in games, in my opinion only works if the game is open world, and this game is not open world.The soundtrack in this game is weird. I can't even say if it's good or bad. But it is off in most places and situation, with exceptions of some levels. Let's just say I had to turn off the ingame music, and opening my own music software for the BGM. But that's just me though.In conclusion, this game has great pixel art style, gameplay is very good and level designs are okay. The only things that turned me off was  the ingame music, and the hassle of not knowing where to actually go next to progress, due to the vague guide and lack of text. I do recommend this game, but only to those who wants the challenge and also appreciates beautiful pixel art, like I do.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2016
												Hyper Light Drifter is everything I wanted it to be. I have been waiting for a game like this since Bit.Trip Runner, which may not make a lot of sense, but let me explain.Bit. Trip Runner is an absorbing game. You must focus at all times, as there is always an obstacle coming right up ahead. The rhythm aspect goes very well with it, as every obstacle you clear makes a sound adding to the music playing, and the music adding another layer of melody to the song every time you collect a core. It's very difficult, very satisfying, and very absorbing.Hyper Light Drifter accomplishes this is a whole new way.It's not a rhythm game, and it's not a platformer. It's an open-world adventure game collectathon. The absorbingness (I know that's not a word) is accomplished by--The environment-The tight and very satisfying combat-The unclear (but clearable) storyline-The soundThe environment is bursting with life. If someone told me this game was made with a level making tool, I would deny it until they proved it.The combat is very challenging and very satisfying. Every enemy poses a different threat, and it's easy to charge them when they're alone, but you must think about the situation fast when multiple enemies of differing types block  your path.The "cutscenes" usually consist of images or certain characters/enemies attacking the Drifter, yet he always seems to survive. The story is very vague, but if you're up for some translation, you can solve the mysteries.The sound is cinematic. One particular moment that struck me was while I was climbing a mountain, and I reached a vantage point to view the mountain, and I saw a giant being frozen in time, perfectly matching my emotion as the sound suddenly changes to a deeper, louder tone.Another thing is the rumbling on beat to the heartbeat when you get to really low health. I really like that one.I find myself yelling "No!" when I die during a crucial moment, I'm that invested in it. Now, if you don't like collectathons, don't immediately dismiss this game; you don't need to collect very much to progress the story. Now, if you are a big fan of this game (like myself), you want to explore all the nooks and crannies, and really see the world this game hides from you. If you have an eye for secrets in video games, you will have a hayday discovering all the secret paths and invisible floors.Get dis game :D

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												TL;DR Great game, great graphics.Bosses are very hard but I think the game doesn't want you to engage them early.Really enjoying my time with this game. I expected it to be a 4-6 hours "linear" story but it actually has a somewhat open world and 0 hand holding. First issue I had is that the game doesn't explain anything to you, nothing is in english and nobody speaks english in the game. Until I started playing it was quite hard to understand what all of the things you see mean. For example, the main objective of the game is explained by a hologram where you have 3 images and you don't even know what those 3 images even are until you start actually playing the game.The game has 0 hand holding, meaning you are put into this world, you get somewhat of an explaination about what you have to do and you can go anywhere you want. There are 4 "areas" in which you have to gather some kind of shards that will later I guess activate this thing that is in center of your "hub" area. What I like is that the game doesn't tell you "go here first" but rather "pick any of these paths".One thing that is really bothering me is the aiming with the weapons. I personally don't use controllers that often and this game is certainly designed to be played with one because I encountered some weird stuff going on with keyboard an mouse.I would like if there was some kind of aim assist or actually lock on mode. The game lets you shoot your weapons without aiming as long as you are pointing the desired direction but in middle of the battle you definitely have no time to aim and let alone orient yourself towards enemies. Another thing worth pointing out is the fact that bosses are insanely hard, but I think the game doesn't want you to engage them early on. Because the game lets you explore the whole map I think it wants you to gather upgrade points and get some skills and then go and engage the bosses because going in without a single skill is pretty much suicide. Bosses have insane amount of health while you have only 5 hp and there are hits that do like 3 points of damage, knocks you down and by the time you get up you are dead. I am going to see if the boss battles get any easier later down the road when you get some skills and upgrades but other than that and the aiming I am really enjoying the game.UPDATE:Finally managed to beat 1 boss. Took me like 1 hour... It honestly isn't as hard as it is more developing a tactic and timing your hits/dashes.

												This is probably one of the best games I've ever played. The art is amazing, the music fits perfectly, the gameplay is super snappy. You can tell a lot of thought was put into almost every little detail and I love games like that. Grats on such a wonderful game, Heart Machine!

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												Imagine a Zelda game set in the future. Then pump that up to ELEVEN.In Hyper Light Drifter you play a nameless wandering soldier with a sword on a quest of unknown purpose, plagued by an unknown illness and haunted by nightmares of death and destruction. You aren't given a clear picture of the goal, or even what you should do NEXT most of the time, but that's okay. Much like a classic Zelda game, you have freedom to explore and do as you please, and discover new secrets for yourself, and there are a TON.The game is also much more action-packed. From the start you are equipped with a "dash" function which can be spammed as often as desired (although there is a slight pause after using it 3 times in a row). The primary function of this dash is to let your character leap over short gaps between platforms, but it's also quite useful for dodging and weaving through the battlefield, approaching enemies for the kill and making a quick escape from a big attack. Players will be encouraged to use the dash as much as desired, and mastery will result in some of the flashiest, high-speed ninja fights ever seen in a Zelda-style game!There are shops in town that sell you incredible but not-altogether-necessary upgrades, such as new moves you can do with your sword, more ammo for your guns (THERE ARE GUNS BY THE WAY), and a grenade to add to your movekit.Heavy on story and gameplay with absolutely no dialogue (the game foregoes dialogue in favor of imagery), freedom of exploration reminiscent of oldschool Zelda games and some high-intensity action-packed combat for you hack-and-slash nuts, although calling it that is a dis-service as lack of care or thought given to when and how you move and strike will leave you dead. But, anyway, the game is amazing, okay?Did I mention it's difficult? Punishingly so, at times, but in a good way that makes you feel like you're learning how to do something each time you 'die'.If I have one piece of advice for you, it's start in the east. When you beat it, you get a shotgun!!!

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												I have a hard time getting engaged with retro and pixel graphics games. Hyper Light Drifter (HLD) somehow has managed to grab my full attention. With the fitting music, ease of control, and threat of enemies keeping me engaged in what I'm doing, HLD is suddenly one of my favorite games.HLD is commonly reported as too difficult. I have experienced some frustration but even playing with a mouse + keyboard the game is really more about not overextending. Bosses are difficult with mouse + keyboard as the dash ability benefits from analog precision but the first boss isn't that hard...died roughly 10 times because I was newbish, using keyboard, and not following the boss cues.The story is purely without text and the UI has no text so I don't know what I'm doing exactly. The pictures portray the NPC story well however the ultimate end, why, who are unclear.The gripes I have with HLD are my own and not a real fault for HLD. First there are so many secrets around that I find myself running along walls so not to miss something (most secrets are marked but not all). Sometimes I enter a new space where the enemies spawn off screen and get free pot shots as they enter. There are long term locked doors scattered around that can't be passed until you've got more of the game completed so don't forget where you saw those doors...Combat is fluid and easy to pick up. Enemies are diverse and the maps alter your options and often give opportunity to look like you planned the whole fight.HLD is great fun with the right amount of challenge. Even if you don't appreciate retro or pixel games check it out; I'm surprised how much I enjoy HLD

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												This game is the pure definition of "struggle", in both tricky scenarios that the game puts you through, as well as the dialouge-free story that it conveys to the player. Dying goes from a set back to an oppurtunity to try again, and again, and again, until you finally advance after hours of pattern memorization and just plain luck. The vibrant colors mask the bleak atmosphere and surreal visuals the game provides, making it just as terrifying as it is mysterious when you come across more and more of the world. Laslty, the ending perfectly ties the pieces to it all, though it takes some deeper reading and exploration to really understand (this game has a lot of plot related secrets), and serves as an emotional payoff to all the hardwork you did. My only gripe is that the new game plus adds a sort of faux-difficulty by simply lowering your health, though it is only a bonus for most diehard completionists. All in all, Hyper Light Drifter is an solid game that deserves a spot as a Game of the Year, at least for me.

Posted: June 26, 2016
												Hyper Light Drifter is the first game I backed on Kickstarter that's been released and I didn't regret backing. My only real complaint is that I feel it's too short – but I suppose that's better than being too long.The combat is great. After playing the Kickstarter demo late last year, I was unsure of if it was going to be too much of a challenge for me, but I had since acquired a controller and it made a huge difference. The combat is punishingly hard, but not unfairly so – every time I died in this game I knew I had screwed up, that I zigged when I should have zagged. I've read a lot of comparisons to Dark Souls and haven't played those games, but I imagine this is what people mean. In a few cases I wish some of the bosses were a bit harder.As far as the exploration aspects go, the game holds your hand just enough to propel you to the ending. If you want more, to see what's behing those mysterious doors you can't open, to get to those areas just off the edge of your screen, you're going to have to work at it. I've seen some comparisons to Zelda here, but if anything I wish Zelda games were a bit more like HLD.I loved the vibe of this game. Everything from the color scheme and depicition of a world of ancient ruins whose origins we'll never know, the lack of any words or dialog to explain what's going on, and Disasterpeace's amazing soundtrack all fit together to make a world I didn't want to leave.

Posted: September 13, 2016
												I don't like writing reveiws, think that no one will bother reading them, but this...is a thing i must write about.It is not nescessary for something to be hyper realistic and jaw droppingly good looking to be considered a masterpiece. Hyperlight drifter is such a thing. It is a 2D, pixelated, hack n' slash, platformer taking place on a post apocalipty earth-like planet. War over the mysterious energy source discovered/ or created by the mysterious race of "Librarians" ravaged the land. What these creatures had left behind now haunts the surviving outscirts of other four (Bird-,otter-,rakoon-,lizard-like humanoid) races. Travel through four regions and discover a great history of once glorious civilizations, while though naration of absolutely no word spoken, not even written visiuals while the story is open for interpretation.Gameplay.Gameplay is simple and straightforward yet challenging, every enemy needs their special approach or they might overwhelm you. They have health bars with squares (each square represents how many hits they can take). You have a sword and six types of guns (Unlocked after deafiting bosses). Each gun usess up ammo you get from destroying the enemy or breakable items. It also includes special dashes allowing player to get from platfrom to platform, or to travel quickly (Can be upgreaded by hidden golden chips). The mechanics are unique, but i'll leave it up to you to discover.World. The World feels "Alive", almost every level, every little location or hidden section tells it's own unwritten tragic story for player to discover. I do believe that not one night was put into the design. Audio is miraculous and lovable with music that seemingly is a cacauphony alone, but turns into a symphony combined with visuals and other sounds. Every sector has its own original music. Evemies are original and every single one has their own characteristics and unique looks, guaranteed to stay fresh and new. I beat that game in three days and already managed to form my own theories of it. Yet what i have to say about it is how almost every item in the game is hidden and by a sheer luck or a guide one can find it, it dries my blood!StoryThe story is left open for interpretaiton, as it is told through visions, enviroments and pictures that appear next to characters when you speak to them. Every character is unique and likable.Verdict.The game is worth EVERY single penny you spend, Great world, great characters, great audio, Great enemis, nice combat but frustratig exploration, just be ready for that. P.s What IGN was unfair in was that they gave HLD 7.6 and one of the cons was "Abstract story telling" while the same company Used the same thing as pro on a game called "Inside". Personally I think this type storrytelling is its pride, the great story given...no word spoken...No subtitles tu read no long cutscenes to see. Only action and a bit of back tracking.9/10

Posted: April 15, 2016
												After 16h I finished the game, I felt sad, sad for this history to end, sad to leave this amazing world that showed so much with so few words.Hyper Light Drifter is an amazing game that almost fell apart due to some technical shortcomings.Let’s get to the bad first:-	 This is an action game locked to 30fps. I think that all games running at 60 fps give us a better experience, versus running at 30fps. That’s not to say 30fps is unplayable, but is a fact.  (Update 20160927 - Devs released a 60 fps build)-	While playing 90% of the game using my xbox360 controller, I always felt the dashing was easier and more responsive using KB+M. I don’t know if this was due to the 30fps lock or no. But the parts of the game where you need to dash like crazy, where made using KB+M.-	Lack of directions plays good for the most part, but can get you frustrated if you stumble into a difficulty spike.Now the good:-	Art Direction: Oh my god, what a beautiful world, I can’t call this retro style, the only thing retro is the resolution, and everything else is PIXEL ART at its finest!-	Music: For the most part simplistic, but setting the tone along the journey.-	Combat: Even locked at 30fps, the combat always felt great, with every enemy careful introduced until you starts to face all of them together, and you starts to dance around then, “a dance of dead”.-	History: Story without words, only art and context. I ended the game caving for more, needing to know more about this world, how it came to be. But I’m glad with the direction they choose, always leaving me hanging for the next screen.I just want to leave a note about exploration: You need to explore to find the secrets, but you always felt imposed to hug every wall, every corner to find then. I think they should have chosen another mechanic for this, leaving a few secretes well hidden, but the rest (the majority) in a way where the scenario hinted us for they existence.If you like to explore a mysterious world and fight like a samurai; and can cope with the 30fps lock , go for it. Hyper Light Drifter is amazing!

Posted: April 2, 2016
												My oversimplified review of Hyper Light Drifter is - imagine the combat and graphics of Crawl mashed up with the world exploration and story of Ori and the Blind Forest. It's a very simple, straightforwad game that marks a lot of boxes in terms of amazing game design and concise yet satisfying storytelling. VERY low amount of instruction, and the design does a great job making sure you get a handle of the controls and movement just moments after starting. From what I understand, the game is also non-linear, which is my favorite part so far. The soundtrack is also incredible. Very ambient and compliments the world tremendously. Disasterpeace never fails to impress.The only con I see in this game is difficulty and how dying is handled. The difficulty can spike in certain areas in terms of platforming and combat. This isn't too bad because you have infinite lives. HOWEVER, every time you die, there is a 3-5 second animation that plays when your character respawns. I know it doesn't sound like an inconvenience, but in areas where you are constantly dying from trying to figure out a platforming puzzle, it makes for a bit of a frustrating experience. As far as I know there is no way to skip this animation.(EDIT: You can now hold down A and X to speed up the respawn animation!)EXTRA NOTE: As of writing this, Steam says I have 7.6 hours of this game logged. I'd like to let it be known that about 2 hours of that was spent trying to reach 800 chain dashes in the dash shop area. I finally accomplished it. I have no regrets.
